Chemical Synthesis and Pollution Control Key Laboratory of Sichuan Province China West Normal University Nanchong Sichuan 637002 China The Knoevenagel condensation reaction is one of the most effective methods for the formation of C–C bonds. However, developing efficient heterogeneous catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction is imperative. In this study, a series of boron carbon nitride (BCN) catalysts with adjustable active sites were designed via molecular self-assembly and calcination-temperature adjustment. The BCN materials synthesized at a calcination temperature of 750 °C (BCN-750) had the largest number of active sites and exhibited excellent activity, with a yield of 96% in the condensation reaction of benzaldehyde and malononitrile in only 4 min at room temperature. The excellent catalytic activity was attributed to the B and N species at the B–N–C sites, which functioned as acids and bases, respectively, to catalyze the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. This result was confirmed by temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2 TPD), temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3 TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and 11B solid-state magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. In addition, aromatic and aliphatic aldehydes were successfully converted into their corresponding products. Analysis of the catalytic mechanism revealed that the deprotonation of malononitrile to form a carbanion was the rate-determining step. Introduction α, β-unsaturated compounds are crucial intermediates in the production of pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals, such as therapeutic drugs (niphendipine and nitrendipine) [1] and polymers containing various functional groups [2]. The Knoevenagel condensation reaction is commonly used to synthesize α, β-unsaturated compounds [3]. Initially, liquid organic weak bases or ammonium salts were used as homogeneous catalysts in the Knoevenagel condensation reaction [4,5]; however, homogeneous catalysts are difficult to separate and recycle. To solve this problem, heterogeneous catalysts have been used for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. As an inexpensive and easy-to-prepare material, carbon nitride (CN) comprising rich basic groups, such as amino [6] and pyrrole groups [7], can theoretically catalyze the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. However, the activity of basic CN alone is low; therefore, various methods have been used to improve the catalytic performance of CN, such as surface modification and pore creation. Krishnan et al. [8] introduced -SO3H groups into g-C3N4, which catalyzed the Knoevenagel condensation reaction of benzaldehyde with malononitrile. Talapaneni et al. [9] used KIT-6 as a hard template to prepare a three-dimensional cubic mesoporous C3N4 catalyst. Although a series of modification methods have been applied to CN, its catalytic activity in the Knoevenagel condensation reaction remains unsatisfactory. Introducing B atoms into CN can reduce the degree of electron conjugation in the tri-s-triazine ring [10], and the B species can function as acidic sites to catalyze the Knoevenagel condensation reaction with the basic sites in CN. Moreover, boron carbon nitride (BCN) materials can be obtained using different methods [11,12] and applied to the Knoevenagel condensation reaction [13]. However, the use of BCN materials has disadvantages; e.g., the catalyst precursors (BCl3 or ionic liquids containing B atoms) are expensive, toxic solvents, such as toluene and n-butanol are used, and high temperatures are required in the catalytic Knoevenagel condensation reaction. In addition, more information is needed to increase the number of uncoordinated B and N species and understand the catalytic mechanism of the Knoevenagel condensation catalyzed by BCN materials. In this study, a BCN catalyst was prepared with adjustable active sites that can efficiently catalyze the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. The number of B–N–C active sites in the catalyst was controlled via molecular self-assembly and calcination- temperature adjustment. In addition, the B and N species in the active sites were uncoordinated and functioned as acidic and basic sites, respectively, to catalyze the Knoevenagel reaction. Experiments on the catalytic mechanism revealed that the rate-determining step was the deprotonation of malononitrile to form a carbanion. These findings provide insight into the development of multifunctional BCN materials as heterogeneous catalysts for broader acid–base organocatalysis reaction. Experimental section Materials Boric acid (>99.5%, Greagent), melamine (98% TCl), dichloromethane (99%, KESHI), absolute ethanol (AR, KESHI), petroleum ether (AR, KESHI), ethyl acetate (AR, KESHI), benzaldehyde (99% KESHI), malononitrile (99%, aladdin), ethyl cyanoacetate (99%, damas-beta), 4-methylbenzaldehyde (97%, aladdin), 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde (99%, damas-beta), 2-methoxybenzaldehyde (99%, damas-beta), 3-methoxybenzaldehyde (99%, damas-beta), 4-methoxybenzaldehyde (99%, aladdin), 4-bromobenzaldehyde (99%, damas-beta), 2-bromobenzaldehyde (98%, aladdin), 4-chlorobenzaldehyde (99%, damas-beta), 2-chlorobenzaldehyde (99%, damas-beta), 4-nitrobenzaldehyde (99%, damas-beta), furan-2-carbaldehyde (99%, damas-beta), thiophene-2-carbaldehyde (99%, damas-beta), pentanal (97%, aladdin), butyraldehyde (99%, damas-beta). Characterization The BCN samples were characterized using scanning electron microscopy (SEM; ZEISS Sigma 500), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy (Nicolet-6700), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD; DX-2700BH), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Thermo ESCALAB 250XI), 11B solid-state magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR)) spectroscopy (Bruker AVANCE III HD 400 MHz Wide Bore Solid State), CO2 TPD, and NH3 TPD (Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920). The structures of certain products were characterized using 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy (Bruker AVANCE 400), and the yields of certain products were determined using gas chromatography (GC; Agilent 7890A). Preparation of BCN The BCN materials were prepared via previously reported methods [14,15]. First, melamine (1 g, 7.92 mmol) and boric acid (1.47 g, 23.77 mmol) were added to a 250 mL beaker containing 90 mL of deionized water. The solution was heated at 90 °C for 3 h until the majority of the water evaporated and a white mixture was formed. The mixture was then freeze-dried for 12 h. The precursor was placed in a covered porcelain boat and heated to a specified temperature (550, 650, 750, 850 or 950 °C) for 4 h at a heating rate of 5 °C·min−1. The corresponding products were designated as BCN-X, where X represents the calcination temperature. For example, BCN-550 was the product of calcination at 550 °C. Preparation of g-C3N4 The g-C3N4 samples were prepared using a previously reported method [16]. Melamine (6 g, 47.57 mmol) was placed in a covered porcelain boat and heated under the following conditions: 550 °C, N2, 4 h, heating rate of 5 °C·min−1. Following calcination. They were denoted as g-C3N4. Catalytic test First, benzaldehyde (1 mmol) and malononitrile (1.2 mmol) were placed in a 10 mL test tube containing 10 mg of catalyst and 1 mL of solvent. The mixture was stirred for 4 or 20 min at 25 °C, and then methylene chloride was added. The catalyst was separated via centrifugation, and parts of the products were isolated. The yields of the products were determined via 1H NMR spectroscopy or GC. In addition, the structures of the products were determined via 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy, and the results are presented in the Supporting Information. For the recycling experiments, the separated catalyst was washed with methylene chloride and dried. The collected catalyst was reused under the same conditions, and the conversion rate of benzaldehyde was confirmed using GC. Results and discussion Morphology and structure of BCN The morphologies of the samples were characterized using SEM. The precursor obtained via molecular self-assembly exhibited a fibrous morphology, as shown in Fig. 1 (a). The calcination product, i.e., BCN-750, exhibited a similar morphology, as shown in Fig. 1(b). BCN-750 exhibited a bamboo-sheet structure at a high-magnification, as shown in Fig. 1(c), and the as-prepared BCN-750 comprised B, C, N, and O atoms, which were homogeneously distributed in the selected area. The morphologies of the other products are similar to those of BCN-750 (Fig. S1). Fig. S2 shows the XRD curves of the BCN-X materials. For BCN-550, the peaks at approximately 24° and 43° corresponded to the (002) and (100) planes of BCN, respectively [17]. The (002) lattice plane was related to the d -spacing [18]. All the samples prepared at different calcination temperatures exhibited similar XRD peaks. Increasing the calcination temperature caused the peak to shift to higher angles; the peak intensity gradually increased, indicating increased crystallinities of the samples [19]. The FTIR spectra of BCN-X are presented in Fig. 2 . Clearly, the different BCN samples exhibited similar characteristic peaks. The peaks at approximately 3400 and 3200 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibrations of the O–H and N–H bonds, respectively [20]. The peak at approximately 1600 cm−1 was attributed to the C=N bonds [21]. The peak at approximately 1400 cm−1 was assigned to the stretching vibration of the B–N–C bonds. Moreover, when the calcination temperature increased from 550 to 750 °C, the peak intensity increased, indicating that the relative content of B–N–C bonds increased. When calcination temperature increased to 950 °C, the peak intensity decreased, indicating that the relative content of B–N–C bonds decreased. The peak at approximately 1100 cm−1 was attributed to the bending vibration of the B–O bonds [22]. With an increase in the calcination temperature, its intensity decreased, indicating that the relative content of B–O bonds decreased. The peak at approximately 800 cm−1 was assigned to the out-of-plane B–N bending vibrations [23]. As the calcination temperature increased, its intensity increased, indicating that the relative content of B–N bonds increased. According to these results, the B–O bonds were gradually converted into B–N bonds from BCN-550 to BCN-950, indicating the successful preparation of the BCN samples. The chemical states of the elements on the surfaces of solid materials can be determined using XPS. The full-range spectra are displayed in Fig. 3 (a). Compared with that for g-C3N4, a new B 1 s peak appeared at approximately 191.0 eV for BCN-X, indicating the successful doping of B atoms. For the BCN-X material, the deconvolutions of B 1 s, N 1 s, and C 1 s are shown in Figs. 3(b)–(d), and the deconvolution of O 1 s is shown in Fig. S3. The high-resolution B 1 s spectra (Fig. 3(b)) can be deconvolved into two peaks at approximately 190.7 and 192.3 eV, which correspond to the B–N and B–O bonds, respectively [24]. Increasing the calcination temperature increased the relative content of B–N bonds and reduced the relative content of B–O bonds, which was consistent with the FTIR results. For the high-resolution N 1 s spectra (Fig. 3c)), the peaks at 398.2, 398.7, 400.0, and 401.8 eV were assigned to the N–B bonds [25], B–N–C bonds [26], pyridine/pyrrole N [27], and N–H bonds [28], respectively. With an increase in the calcination temperature, the relative content of N–B bonds increased from 47% to 65% for BCN-550 and BCN-950, respectively (Table 1 ). The relative content of pyridine/pyrrole N decreased from 13% to 0% for BCN-550 and BCN-950, respectively, possibly owing to the breaking of the triazine ring and part of the C=N bonds leaving the system in the form of HCN [29]. When the calcination temperature of the precursor was increased from 550 to 750 °C, the relative content of B–N–C in BCN-X gradually increased from 24% to 41%, which may have been be due to the break of the triazine ring, and numerous B–N–C bonds were formed. When the calcination temperature of the precursor was increased to 950 °C, the relative content of B–N–C in BCN-X gradually decreased to 35%, possibly owing to the reduction of the C content (Table S1). The high-resolution spectra of C 1 s are shown in Fig. 3(d). The peak at approximately 284.7 eV was assigned to graphitic C, and may have been due to C impurities [30]. The peak at approximately 286.2 eV was assigned to C–O/C–N bonds [31]. The C–O bonds resulted from the reaction of the hydroxyl group in boric acid with the amino groups of melamine [32]. The peak at 288.7 eV corresponds to the N–C=N bonds [33], which may have been part of the triazine ring. As shown in the high-resolution O 1 s spectra (Fig. S3), there were two peaks at 532.5 and 532.9 eV, which were assigned to the O–B [34] and O–C bonds [35], respectively. These results are consistent with the FTIR spectra. The chemical state of the B species in BCN-X was characterized using 11B solid-state MAS NMR. For BCN-550, the 11B solid-state MAS NMR signals were attributed to the structures (i) (δ iso≈ 25 ppm) [36], (ii) (δ iso≈ 21 ppm) [37], (iii) (δ iso≈ 16 pm) [38], (iv) (δ iso≈ 12 ppm) [39], and (v) (δ iso≈ 0.9 ppm) [40] (Fig. 4 (a)). The 11B solid-state MAS NMR spectra of BCN-750 and BCN-950 (Figs. 4(b) and (c), respectively) are similar to that of BCN-550. As shown in Table 2 , increasing the calcination temperature increased the relative content of structures (i) and (ii), and the chemical shift values shifted slightly toward the low-field region, indicating that more B–N bonds were formed. Structure (iv) corresponded to polyborate compounds, which may have been formed the self-polymerization of boronic acid molecules at high temperatures. The conjugate base of boric acid is B(OH)4 − in an aqueous solution. The hydroxyl group in B(OH)4 − and an amino group in melamine formed the aggregates via hydrogen bonds. The aggregates were then dehydrated at a certain temperature to form structure (v). The relative contents of structures (iii), (iv), and (v) decreased with an increase in the calcination temperature. According to the results, the structure of BCN-X approached that of hexagonal BN (h-BN) [41] with the increase in the calcination temperature. Formation and measurement of acid–base sites on BCN materials According to the FTIR, XPS, and 11B solid-state MAS NMR analyses, the formation process of BCN-X (Fig. 5 ) is presented. First, boric acid and melamine formed the precursors via self-assembly [42]. When the calcination temperature was 550 °C, the B–N and B–O bonds were formed by the reaction of the hydroxyl group in boric acid and the amino group in melamine, which released H2O and NH3, respectively [43]. When the calcination temperature was 750 °C, the triazine ring in melamine was cleaved, and the –CNH– and C–O bonds were leaved in the form of HCN and CO2, respectively [29]. When the calcination temperature was 950 °C, the precursor released HCN, CO2, NH3, and H2O during the heating process. Moreover, the C content of BCN-950 was further reduced (Table S1); thus, so the structure of BCN-950 gradually became similar to that of h-BN. From the perspective of the catalyst structure, the BCN-750 sample contained abundant B–N–C active sites, which were conducive to the substrate reaction on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, a strong positive correlation between the conversion rate of benzaldehyde and the relative content of B–N–C indicated that the B–N–C may have been the active species in the reaction (Fig. S4). The incorporation of C into the h-BN framework induced acid sites (undercoordinated B sites) and increased the density of base sites (undercoordinated N sites) [44]. Therefore, the undercoordinated B and N sites in the B–N–C fragment exhibit acidity and basicity after accepting an additional lone-pair electron and donating a lone-pair electron, respectively. The acidity and alkalinity of BCN-X samples can be determined via NH3 TPD and CO2 TPD, respectively. In the NH3 TPD profiles (Fig. 6 (a)), the BCN-550, BCN-750, and BCN-950 samples exhibited a single peak at 138, 146, and 147 °C, respectively. The presence of the single peak, indicated that a weak acid site was primarily present in the samples [45]. Moreover, there was a gradual shift of the peak position from 138 to 147 °C, indicating that the acidity of the samples gradually increased. In the CO2 TPD profiles (Fig. 6(b)), the BCN-550, BCN-750, and BCN-950 samples exhibited a single peak at 157, 175, and 170 °C, respectively. The presence of single peak, indicated that a weak base site was primarily present in the samples [46]. In addition, BCN-750 sample exhibited the highest peak position, indicating that it was the most alkaline. The increased alkalinity of the sample with an increase in the calcination temperature was attributed to an increase in the relative content of B–N–C. However, when the temperature was too high, excessive loss of C occurred, reducing the alkalinity (Table S1). For the calcination temperature of 750 °C, BCN-750 exhibited suitable acidity and alkalinity, according to the relative content of B–N–C. Catalysis performance of BCN-X The Knoevenagel condensation reaction of benzaldehyde and malononitrile was used as a template reaction (Scheme 1 ) to evaluate the catalyst performance and optimize the reaction conditions. Fig. 7 (a) shows the conversion rate of benzaldehyde over different catalysts. When g-C3N4 or no catalyst was used, the conversion rate of benzaldehyde was extremely low. Using BCN-X as the catalyst for the template reaction significantly improved the conversion rate of benzaldehyde. For BCN-750, the conversion rate of benzaldehyde reached 86%, and the selectivity reached 99%. Furthermore, the solvent polarity significantly influences the Knoevenagel condensation reaction [47]; water is used to change the polarity of the reaction system. As shown in Fig. 7(b), when the solvent was water or ethanol, the conversion rate of benzaldehyde was low. Conversely, when the solvent was a mixture of water and ethanol (0.75:0.25 mL v/v), the benzaldehyde conversion rate was the highest (94%). To investigate the effect of the solvent volume on the template reaction, the polarity of the solvent was kept unchanged; as shown in Fig. 7(c), the amount of solvent had little effect on the reaction. Finally, the effect of the reaction time on the template reaction was investigated, as shown in Fig. 7(d). As the reaction time increased, the benzaldehyde conversion rate increased. When the reaction time was 4 min, the conversion rate of benzaldehyde was close to 96%; however, extending the reaction time had little effect on the benzaldehyde conversion. Therefore, under the optimized reaction conditions of 25 °C, 4 min, 1 mL of solvent (ethanol:water = 0.75:0.25 mL), 1.2:1 molar ratio of malononitrile (1.2 mmol) to benzaldehyde, and 10 mg of BCN-750 catalyst, the conversion rate of benzaldehyde was 96.0%, and the selectivity was 99%. To study the generality of the procedure, the reactions of aldehyde derivatives with active methylene compounds catalyzed by BCN-750 under the optimum reaction conditions were investigated. As shown in Table 3 , when the substituents on the aromatic aldehyde were electron-donating groups, such as methoxy or methyl groups (Entries 2–6), the yields of the corresponding products are good. When the substituents on an aromatic aldehyde are electron-withdrawing groups, such as nitro groups or halogen-substituted benzaldehydes (Entries 7–11), the products are easily obtained in excellent yields. According to the Hammett equation (Fig. 8 (a)), the substituent has little effect on the reaction. For aliphatic and heterocyclic aldehydes (Entries 12–15), the catalyst efficiently catalyzes the reactions, yielding the corresponding products. When the active methylene compound is ethyl cyanoacetate, the conversion rate of benzaldehyde is improved by increasing the temperature, the reaction time, and the polarity of the solvent (Entry 16). Moreover, the product structure was determined using 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy. Finally, the stability of the catalyst was evaluated via cyclic experiments. The catalytic effect of the catalyst was well maintained for the first five cycles (Fig. 8(b)). A comparison between the as-prepared BCN-750 and previously reported catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde and malononitrile is presented in Table 4 . The as-prepared BCN-750 catalyst has the following advantages: (1) the solvent is more eco-friendly, (2) the reaction proceeds smoothly at room temperature, and (3) the reaction achieves a high yield in a short time. In addition, the catalytic efficiency of the as-prepared BCN-750 catalyst is higher than those of the other catalysts (Table 4), which confirms the high efficiency of the as-prepared BCN-750 catalyst and contributes to its significant application prospects. Possible mechanism of Knoevenagel condensation reaction catalyzed by BCN-750 According to the above experimental results and previous reports [52,53], a possible reaction mechanism is proposed (Fig. 9 ). First, the B atoms activate the carbonyl group on benzaldehyde, whereas the lone-pair electrons on the N atoms attack the active H+ ion from malononitrile, forming carbanion. The carbanion of malononitrile attacks the carbonyl group of benzaldehyde, forming negative O ions. Next, the H+ ions from the N atoms are transferred to the negative O ions. Finally, water molecules and products are obtained, and the structure of the BCN-750 catalyst returns to its pre-reaction state. The reaction process was further investigated through the experimental results. Various active methylene compounds were reacted with benzaldehyde (Table S2). The results indicated that the yields decreased with the decreasing acidity of malononitrile, ethyl cyanoacetate, and diethyl malonate. In addition, ethyl acetoacetate negligibly reacted with benzaldehyde upon heating, even with a prolonged reaction time, indicating that the dehydrogenation of active methylene compounds to carbanions may be the rate-determining step. Furthermore, the yield of 2-(4-hydroxybenzylidene) malononitrile (Entry 3) was the lowest; therefore, p-hydroxybenzaldehyde may be acidic, hinders the deprotonation process (Scheme 2 ). When 1.2 mmol of phenol was added to the template reaction system, the conversion rate of benzaldehyde was only 50% of the original product. This result indicates that strong acidity reverses the movement of the reaction (Scheme 2), and the conversion rate of benzaldehyde decreases. Finally, when low polarity ethanol was used as the solvent, the conversion rate of benzaldehyde was low. When a small volume of water was added to the system, the polarity of the system increased, and the reaction activity significantly improved. These results indicate that the reaction occurred readily when the polarity of the solvent increased, possibly because the higher polarity stabilized the carbanions. Moreover, steric hindrance and electronic effects had little influence on the reaction (Fig. 8(a)), indicating that the attack of the carbanion on the carbonyl group was not the rate-determining step. Therefore, the formation of the carbanion in an easy and stable manner is critical for increasing the yield. Conclusions BCN catalysts with a controllable number of active sites were prepared via molecular self-assembly and calcination-temperature adjustment. Experiment results revealed that BCN-750 had excellent catalytic performance, and the yield of benzylidene malononitrile reached 96% within 4 min. This excellent catalytic activity originated from the rich B–N–C active sites. The mechanism analysis revealed that the uncoordinated B and N species in the B–N–C sites functioned as acids and bases, respectively, catalyzing the reaction, and that the deprotonation of active methylene compounds was the rate-determining step of the reaction. BCN catalysts can be used for other acid–base catalytic reactions, and our teams is currently conducting research on this topic. coredata.dc:description: The Knoevenagel condensation reaction is one of the most effective methods for the formation of C–C bonds. However, developing efficient heterogeneous catalysts for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction is imperative. In this study, a series of boron carbon nitride (BCN) catalysts with adjustable active sites were designed via molecular self-assembly and calcination-temperature adjustment. The BCN materials synthesized at a calcination temperature of 750 °C (BCN-750) had the largest number of active sites and exhibited excellent activity, with a yield of 96% in the condensation reaction of benzaldehyde and malononitrile in only 4 min at room temperature. The excellent catalytic activity was attributed to the B and N species at the B–N–C sites, which functioned as acids and bases, respectively, to catalyze the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. This result was confirmed by temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2 TPD), temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3 TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and 11B solid-state magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. In addition, aromatic and aliphatic aldehydes were successfully converted into their corresponding products. Analysis of the catalytic mechanism revealed that the deprotonation of malononitrile to form a carbanion was the rate-determining step.
coredata.dc:title: BCN materials with adjustable active sites as heterogeneous acid–base catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation reaction
